ygData.subject: Re: A question about the Double Pole Benchmark / problems with pole balancing
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, yes everything you say is correct.  It is indeed impossible if they are the same length.  (I m not sure about mass.)  If the poles are made more

Colin, yes everything you say is correct.  It is indeed impossible if the=
y are the same length.  (I'm not sure about mass.)  If the poles are made m=
ore similar, the problem becomes a lot harder.  

In fact, the neural netwo=
rk long pictured at the top of the NEAT Users Page (http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~=
kstanley/neat.html) was a solution evolved by NEAT to the DPNV problem at c=
loser lengths.  I believe it used lengths of 1m and 0.3m.  The problem chan=
ges a lot with these lengths, requiring significant internal structure (whe=
reas the usual setup requires almost none).  I'm not sure if we ever report=
ed that result, but one reason I evolved the 0.3/1.0 balancer from scratch =
was because previously the only known way to get one at that setting was by=
 incrementally evolving from a pre-evolved 0.1/1.0 balancer, as reported by=
 Faustino Gomez and Risto Miikkulainen in 1999:

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/u=
sers/nn/downloads/papers/gomez.ijcai99.pdf

So I thought it would be cool i=
f the complexification in NEAT could be shown to preclude the need to incre=
mentally evolve, which it did at the 0.3/1.0 setting.  However, if I rememb=
er right, at even closer settings I think it starts getting too hard to evo=
lve from scratch.  Of course these are very old results so my memory could =
be fuzzy.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin" <colin.green1@...> wro=
te:
>
> Looking over the double pole balancing code again (porting over to =
sharpneat 2) and I'm reminded that this problem is possible because the pol=
es are different lengths. At least I think I'm right in saying that the tas=
k is impossible if the poles are the same length (and/or same mass?).
> 
> =
So anyway I was just thinking that we can alter the difficulty by making th=
e lengths more or less similar. The code as it stands defines the poles as:=

> 
> Pole 1: 1m, 0.1kg
> Pole 2: 0.1m, 0.01kg
> 
> Just though I'd mention=
 this.
> 
> Colin.
>
